DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Source terminated operations of covered process

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Devon Shelby #3 Gas Plant
Executive Summary

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

The Shelby #3 gas plant is committed to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident protection, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The Shelby #3 gas plant, located approximately 12 miles southwest of Center in Shelby County, Texas, operates a Joule-Thompson plant to extract liquid petroleum products from raw natural gas.  The plant products include pipeline quality natural gas (primarily methane) and natural gas liquids comprised of ethane, propane, butane, pentane, and heavier hydrocarbons, some of which are regulated flammable substances.

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS

There are no toxic chemicals stored at the Shelby #3 gas plant above the EPA Threshold Quantity.  The threshold quantity is the level set by the EPA for each toxic or flammable chemical which if stored at the site requires compliance with the EPA?s Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations.  Generally, if the amount of a substance stored on-site is less than the threshold quantity, there is little danger to the public.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Because the process at the Shelby #3 gas plant which is regulated by the EPA RMP rule is not subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, no additional steps for accidental release prevention are required.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases at the Shelby #3 gas plant that have occurred in the past 5 years that have resulted in offsite effects.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATON

The overall emergency response program for the Shelby #3 g

as plant is coordinated with the Shelby County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the local fire department.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.

CONCLUSION

The Shelby #3 gas plant has had very safe operations over its brief history.  However, the facility continually looks for improvements, both to the process and to safety issues at the facility.  Our company is very active in promoting coordination between the local emergency response agencies and our facility personnel.  Ongoing communication between our facility and the emergency responders is a integral part of our operations.
